positive_prompts: I just finished reading a novel my friend recommended three months ago. The way the author wove together multiple storylines kept me engaged until 2am last night. I'm genuinely grateful she pushed me to read it because it's been years since a book affected me this deeply.

My team spent six weeks preparing for yesterday's client presentation. When the CEO said it was exactly what they needed and approved the full budget, the relief in the room was palpable. Seeing my junior colleague's face light up made all those late nights feel worthwhile.

The physical therapist told me I'd need at least four months to recover from the injury. After following her program religiously, I ran my first mile yesterday without any pain. The sense of reclaiming my body and routine has given me a confidence I didn't realize I'd lost.

My grandmother turned 90 last weekend and the whole family gathered at her house. Watching her laugh at old stories with her sister, who flew in from across the country, reminded me what really matters. I left feeling more connected to my roots than I have in a decade.

I've been learning Spanish through an app for eight months now. Yesterday I had my first real conversation with a native speaker at the coffee shop and she understood everything I said. The rush of actually communicating in another language exceeded all my expectations.

The restaurant we tried last night was a small family-owned place tucked away on a side street. Every dish had this careful attention to flavor that you just don't find in chain restaurants. I'm already planning to bring my parents there next month because I know they'll appreciate the authenticity.

My neighbor's dog had been missing for three days and I could see how worried she was. This morning I spotted him two blocks away and managed to catch him before he ran further. The hug she gave me when I brought him back was one of those pure human moments that stays with you.

I spent the entire weekend reorganizing my home office and finally dealing with years of accumulated clutter. Now when I sit down to work, everything has a place and I can actually focus. The mental clarity that comes from a clean space is something I'd forgotten was possible.

The concert last night featured a pianist I've been following for years but never seen live. The way she interpreted pieces I thought I knew well revealed layers I'd completely missed in recordings. I walked out feeling like I'd experienced music rather than just heard it.

My daughter has been struggling with math all semester and we've worked through problems together every evening. Yesterday she came home excited to show me she got a B+ on her test. Watching her realize she's capable of understanding difficult concepts has been more rewarding than any of my own achievements lately.

I took a different route to work this morning and discovered a park I never knew existed in my neighborhood. The early morning light through the trees and the quiet before the city wakes up gave me twenty minutes of peace. I'm making this detour part of my daily routine because that calm carried through my entire day.

The documentary I watched last night explored climate solutions being implemented by small communities worldwide. Instead of the usual doom and gloom, it showed practical examples of people solving real problems. I finished it feeling hopeful and motivated rather than paralyzed by the scale of the crisis.

My old college roommate reached out after five years of minimal contact. We spent three hours on the phone catching up and it felt like no time had passed at all. There's something irreplaceable about friendships that can survive distance and silence and still feel comfortable.

I finally tried that pottery class I'd been putting off for months. Getting my hands dirty and creating something physical after years of only digital work was surprisingly therapeutic. The lopsided bowl I made isn't winning any awards but I'm proud of it in a way I haven't felt about my work in ages.

The new manager started last month and I was skeptical about yet another reorganization. But she actually listened to our concerns, implemented several of our suggestions, and the team dynamic has noticeably improved. It's refreshing to work for someone who treats us like adults with valuable input.

I've been volunteering at the community garden every Saturday for the past two months. Yesterday we harvested the first vegetables and donated them to the local food bank. Seeing something grow from seed to food because of work I contributed to connects me to the community in a tangible way.

My son called from college just to talk, not because he needed money or advice. We ended up discussing philosophy and politics for an hour and I was struck by how thoughtful his perspectives have become. The transition from parenting a child to having an adult relationship with him feels like a privilege.

The book club I joined six months ago has become the highlight of my month. Last night's discussion about memory and identity went until midnight and challenged assumptions I didn't know I had. Finding people who want to engage deeply with ideas in person feels increasingly rare and valuable.

I finally finished the certification program I've been working on for eighteen months. The knowledge itself is useful but what surprised me most was the confidence that comes from proving to myself I can commit to something difficult. I'm already looking at what challenging goal to tackle next.

The veterinarian said our cat probably had a few weeks left and we should prepare ourselves. After starting the new treatment, she's been playing and eating normally for the first time in months. Having more time with her feels like a gift we didn't expect to receive.

I took my nephew to the science museum and watched him spend an hour experimenting with the physics exhibits. His genuine curiosity and willingness to try things multiple ways reminded me of how I used to approach problems. I left wanting to bring that playful experimentation back into my own work.

The hiking trail we chose was more challenging than expected and I almost suggested turning back. But reaching the summit and seeing the valley spread out below made every difficult step worth it. Sometimes the things that require real effort are the ones that stay with you.

My partner surprised me by cooking an elaborate meal from scratch on a random Tuesday. It wasn't a special occasion, just a gesture to show appreciation after a stressful week. Small acts of thoughtfulness like that matter more than grand romantic gestures ever could.

I've been practicing meditation for three months and honestly wasn't sure it was doing anything. Yesterday during a tense meeting I noticed myself staying calm and responding thoughtfully instead of reacting. The subtle shifts in how I handle stress are finally becoming apparent.

The local theater production I saw last night was performed by community members, not professionals. Despite the simple staging, the passion and commitment of the actors made it more engaging than many big-budget shows I've seen. Art created for love rather than profit has a different quality.

I spent yesterday afternoon teaching my father how to use video calls so he can see his grandchildren more often. Watching him figure it out and seeing his face when he successfully called my sister made the patience required completely worthwhile. Technology can genuinely bring families closer when used thoughtfully.

The article I read this morning presented a perspective on a political issue I thought I understood completely. It challenged my assumptions with evidence I hadn't considered and made me realize my position was more nuanced than I'd acknowledged. Being willing to update your views based on new information feels intellectually honest.

My coworker covered my shifts last month when I had a family emergency without making me feel guilty about it. Yesterday when she needed to leave early, I was glad to return the favor. Workplaces function better when people treat each other as humans first and colleagues second.

The yoga instructor I've been taking classes from for years announced she's moving to another city. In her final class, she talked about how the practice is about showing up consistently, not achieving perfection. That lesson applies to so much more than yoga and I'm grateful she articulated it.

I finally cleaned out my email inbox that had accumulated 3,000 unread messages over the years. The mental weight of that pending task was larger than I realized. Now when I open my email I feel in control rather than overwhelmed.

The podcast episode I listened to during my commute featured a scientist explaining her research in accessible terms. Her enthusiasm for discovering how the world works was contagious. I arrived at work energized rather than dreading the day ahead.

My teenager actually asked for my advice about a friendship problem instead of shutting me out. We talked through the situation and I could see her processing different perspectives. These moments of being trusted and useful as a parent are precious because I know they won't last forever.

The farmers market vendor remembered my name and asked how I liked last week's tomatoes. In a world of impersonal transactions, these small connections make the neighborhood feel like a community. I'll keep shopping there even though the supermarket is more convenient.

I decided to walk to the store instead of driving and ran into three neighbors I hadn't seen in months. The conversations were brief but genuine and reminded me that community happens in small moments. Slowing down enough to actually see people makes the neighborhood feel less lonely.

The online course I'm taking has a discussion forum where students from around the world share perspectives. Reading how people from different cultures approach the same problems has expanded my thinking more than the lectures themselves. Global connection through learning feels like technology at its best.

My friend's band played at a small venue last night and I went to support them. They've improved dramatically since I last saw them perform and the crowd's energy was infectious. Watching people pursue creative projects seriously while maintaining day jobs is inspiring.

I finally replaced my worn-out running shoes and the difference was immediately noticeable. My knees don't ache after runs anymore and I'm enjoying the activity again instead of dreading it. Sometimes the solution to a problem is simpler than you think.

The barista at my regular coffee shop has been experimenting with new brewing methods. This morning's cup was noticeably better and when I complimented it, her face lit up. People who care about craft and continuous improvement make ordinary transactions meaningful.

I spent Sunday afternoon at the botanical garden without any agenda or schedule. Sitting on a bench watching people and plants coexist peacefully gave me a sense of calm I didn't know I needed. Unstructured time in beautiful spaces is underrated.

My mentor from early in my career reached out to say she'd heard about my recent promotion. Her message about being proud of my growth meant more than the promotion itself. Having someone who believed in you early on witness your progress feels validating.

The neighborhood kids started a lemonade stand and I stopped to buy a cup. Their entrepreneurial spirit and negotiation over whether to charge 50 cents or a dollar was delightful. Supporting the next generation's first business ventures is worth far more than the overpriced lemonade.

I've been learning to play guitar through online tutorials for six months. Yesterday I played through an entire song without mistakes for the first time. The satisfaction of developing a skill through consistent practice is different from any achievement that came easily.

The documentary about ocean conservation I watched last night was beautifully filmed and scientifically rigorous. It managed to convey urgency without despair and ended with concrete actions individuals can take. Media that educates and empowers rather than just frightening people is valuable.

My sister called to apologize for something that happened years ago that I'd honestly forgotten about. The fact that she'd been carrying it and wanted to clear the air showed emotional maturity. Relationships that can acknowledge mistakes and move forward are the ones worth keeping.

I tried a new recipe that required techniques I'd never attempted before. Despite some imperfections, the dish turned out delicious and I learned skills I can apply to other cooking. Pushing beyond your comfort zone in low-stakes situations builds confidence for when it matters more.

The customer service representative I spoke with yesterday actually solved my problem instead of transferring me endlessly. Her competence and willingness to take ownership of the issue restored my faith in the company. Good service from empowered employees makes all the difference.

I attended a lecture by an author whose work I've admired for years. Hearing her discuss her creative process and the doubts she still experiences was humanizing. Even accomplished people struggle, which makes pursuing difficult things feel less isolating.

My morning routine has finally become automatic after months of forcing myself to stick to it. Waking up early to exercise and read before work has noticeably improved my mood and productivity. The compound effects of small daily habits are real.

The sunset last evening had colors I've rarely seen and I stopped what I was doing to just watch it. Taking five minutes to appreciate natural beauty without photographing it or multitasking felt almost rebellious. Presence is a skill worth cultivating.

My friend group organized a potluck dinner where everyone cooked a dish from their cultural background. The food was excellent but the stories behind each dish and the conversations they sparked were the real gift. Sharing heritage through food creates connection in a way that words alone can't.
negative_prompts: I spent three weeks preparing a proposal that I thought addressed exactly what the client wanted. They rejected it in a five-minute call without real explanation and I'm left wondering what I missed. The frustration of wasted effort combined with not understanding why makes it hard to know how to improve.

My landlord just announced a rent increase that will take 40% of my monthly income instead of 30%. I've looked at other apartments but everything in my area has gotten equally expensive. The stress of choosing between financial stability and moving somewhere unfamiliar weighs on me constantly.

The doctor's appointment I waited six weeks for was rushed and dismissive. She barely looked up from her computer and prescribed the same medication that hasn't been working. Feeling unheard when you're trying to address health concerns makes you lose faith in the system.

I discovered my coworker has been taking credit for work I did on our shared project. When I brought it up with my manager, he said to work it out between ourselves rather than addressing it. The combination of betrayal and lack of support from leadership makes me want to leave.

My flight was delayed four hours with no explanation or compensation offered. By the time I arrived, I'd missed the event I was traveling for and wasted hundreds of dollars. The powerlessness of being at the mercy of airline incompetence is infuriating.

I've been applying to jobs for three months and getting automated rejections or complete silence. Each application takes hours to customize and the lack of any human response makes the whole process feel dehumanizing. My confidence in my abilities is eroding with each rejection.

The restaurant we went to for our anniversary was loud, overpriced, and the service was inattentive. What should have been a special evening turned into an expensive disappointment. Sometimes high expectations make the letdown feel worse than it objectively is.

My car broke down for the third time this year and the mechanic says it needs a major repair that costs more than the car is worth. I can't afford a new car but I can't afford to keep fixing this one either. Being trapped by financial constraints makes every day stressful.

I spent the weekend visiting family and left feeling more drained than when I arrived. The constant criticism disguised as concern and the inability to have a conversation without it becoming an argument is exhausting. Sometimes the relationships that should be supportive are the most depleting.

The project I've been working on for six months just got cancelled due to budget cuts. All that work and creative energy went nowhere and now I'm being reassigned to something I have no interest in. The lack of control over your own time and effort in corporate environments is demoralizing.

My neighbor's dog barks for hours every day and they've ignored my polite requests to address it. The constant noise makes it impossible to focus on work or relax at home. Feeling like you can't have peace in your own space creates a background stress that affects everything.

I trusted a friend with something personal and discovered they'd shared it with others without permission. The betrayal of confidence combined with having to see them regularly in our friend group makes everything awkward. Not knowing who you can trust makes you want to withdraw.

The insurance company denied my claim on a technicality after I'd been paying premiums for years. Fighting their decision requires hours on hold and navigating bureaucracy designed to make you give up. Systems that profit from making it hard to access what you've paid for feel predatory.

I prepared thoroughly for a presentation and technical issues made it impossible to show my work properly. The audience lost interest and I looked unprepared despite having done everything right. Being judged for circumstances beyond your control is deeply frustrating.

My chronic pain has been getting worse and doctors keep suggesting it's stress or in my head. The dismissal of physical symptoms because they can't find an obvious cause makes you feel gaslit. Not being believed when you're suffering adds psychological pain to the physical.

I spent my day off dealing with a billing error that was clearly the company's mistake. After four hours and six different representatives, it's still not resolved. The theft of time and energy to fix problems you didn't create feels like adding insult to injury.

The friend I've made plans with has cancelled at the last minute for the third time in a row. The pattern makes it clear I'm not a priority but they won't just be honest about not wanting to hang out. Being strung along with excuses feels worse than direct rejection.

I've been working overtime for months with promises of recognition that never materialize. Meanwhile, someone who does the minimum gets promoted because they're better at office politics. The injustice of effort not being rewarded makes you question why you try.

The apartment upstairs is being renovated and construction noise starts at 7am every day. I work night shifts and the sleep deprivation is affecting my health and job performance. Having your basic needs disrupted by circumstances you can't control creates a helpless frustration.

I bought a product based on reviews that now seem suspiciously fake. The actual item is poor quality and the return process is deliberately complicated. Feeling deceived and then having to fight to get your money back makes you cynical about online shopping.

My parent's health is declining and they refuse to accept help or make necessary changes. Watching someone you love make choices that hurt them while being unable to intervene is agonizing. The powerlessness of caring deeply but having no control is emotionally exhausting.

The gym I've been a member of for years changed ownership and eliminated the classes I attended. They won't prorate my annual membership or let me cancel without a penalty. Being locked into paying for a service that no longer provides what you signed up for feels like a scam.

I discovered a mistake I made weeks ago that has been causing problems for my team. The guilt of letting people down combined with having to admit the error publicly is mortifying. Knowing you're the source of others' frustration makes you want to disappear.

The concert I bought expensive tickets for months ago was cancelled the day before. The refund doesn't cover the hotel and travel costs I'm now stuck with. Having plans you looked forward to fall apart along with losing money creates a double disappointment.

My teenager has been increasingly withdrawn and hostile and I don't know how to reach them. Every attempt at conversation turns into an argument or silence. The fear that you're failing at the most important job you have is paralyzing.

I've been experiencing symptoms that could be serious but the earliest appointment available is two months away. The anxiety of waiting combined with not knowing if you should be worried is mentally draining. Healthcare systems that can't provide timely access create unnecessary suffering.

The promotion I was promised went to an external hire who knows nothing about our systems. I have to train my new boss while making less money than them. The disrespect of being passed over and then expected to enable someone else's success is enraging.

My credit card information was stolen and used for thousands in fraudulent charges. Despite reporting it immediately, dealing with the aftermath has consumed hours and created stress about identity theft. Feeling violated and then having to do all the work to fix it adds to the violation.

I spent months planning a vacation and got sick the day we were supposed to leave. The trip is non-refundable and I'm too ill to enjoy it even if I force myself to go. Sometimes bad timing makes you feel like the universe is actively working against you.

The book I was excited to read based on recommendations turned out to be poorly written and full of ideas I found offensive. I kept reading hoping it would improve but just wasted time I could have spent on something worthwhile. Disappointment in something you anticipated is particularly deflating.

My basement flooded during the storm and insurance is claiming it's not covered under my policy. The damage is extensive and I can't afford the repairs out of pocket. Discovering you're not protected when you thought you were creates a financial and emotional crisis.

I've been ghosted by someone I thought was becoming a close friend with no explanation. The confusion of not knowing what happened combined with feeling disposable makes you question your judgment. Being treated as if you don't deserve basic courtesy is dehumanizing.

The political situation in my country keeps deteriorating and I feel powerless to affect change. Every news cycle brings fresh outrages and the people in power seem immune to accountability. The erosion of hope that things can improve is spiritually exhausting.

My employer announced layoffs and the uncertainty about whether I'll have a job next month is affecting my sleep and health. The stress of waiting for a decision that will dramatically impact your life but that you have no control over is unbearable.

I tried to address a problem in my community through proper channels and got endless bureaucratic runarounds. The systems meant to help citizens seem designed to discourage participation. Civic engagement that goes nowhere makes you understand why people become apathetic.

The medication I've taken for years is no longer covered by my insurance and the out-of-pocket cost is unaffordable. Rationing or going without something that maintains your health because of insurance company decisions feels dystopian.

I overheard colleagues making fun of something I'd said in a meeting. The realization that people I thought respected me actually mock me behind my back makes every interaction feel false. Not knowing who's genuine makes the workplace feel hostile.

My long-term relationship ended and now I have to see my ex regularly because we share a friend group. The awkwardness and pain of being around them while trying to move on is constant. Social connections that used to bring joy now bring dread.

I've been dealing with a bureaucratic error for months that's preventing me from accessing benefits I'm entitled to. Each person I speak with gives different information and no one takes ownership. Systems that punish you for their mistakes while offering no recourse feel Kafkaesque.

The tree I planted years ago and watched grow was cut down by the city without notice because of utility work. Something I'd nurtured and that gave me joy was destroyed for bureaucratic convenience. The casual destruction of things people care about by institutions feels contemptuous.

I spent a day cooking an elaborate meal for friends and multiple people cancelled at the last minute. The wasted effort and food combined with feeling like an afterthought makes you not want to host again. When people don't value your time and effort, it's hard not to take it personally.

My package was marked delivered but never arrived and the company says it's not their problem. I'm out both the money and the item with no recourse. Being told a problem is your fault when you did nothing wrong makes you feel gaslit.

I've been experiencing discrimination at work but HR says they need more documentation before they'll act. The burden of proving mistreatment while continuing to endure it is traumatic. Systems that protect institutions rather than individuals make seeking help feel pointless.

The repair person I paid in advance never showed up and isn't returning calls. I'm out the money and still have the original problem. Being taken advantage of when you're trying to solve a problem makes you lose faith in people.

My creative project that I poured myself into for months got harsh criticism from someone whose opinion I valued. The rejection of something so personal makes you question whether you should keep trying. Vulnerability that gets met with dismissal makes you want to protect yourself by not creating.

I've been trying to schedule a meeting with my manager for weeks to discuss concerns and keep getting postponed. The message that my issues aren't a priority while being expected to prioritize everything they need is clear. Feeling invisible in your workplace erodes any sense of investment.

The neighborhood I've lived in for years is changing rapidly and the community feel is disappearing. Local businesses are being replaced by chains and I don't recognize people anymore. Watching a place you loved transform into something generic feels like a slow loss.

I discovered a mistake in my medical records that could affect my care and correcting it requires extensive documentation and persistence. The potential consequences of errors you didn't make but have to fix creates anxiety. Systems that make it hard to ensure accuracy put the burden on the wrong person.

My attempt to learn a new skill has been frustrating and progress feels impossibly slow. Watching others pick it up easily while I struggle makes me feel inadequate. The gap between wanting to be good at something and the reality of being a beginner is discouraging.

The warranty on my expensive appliance expired two weeks before it broke down. The repair costs almost as much as a new one and the timing feels deliberately designed. Planned obsolescence and convenient warranty timing makes you feel manipulated by corporations.

design_principles: 3-sentence structure: context, sentiment with specificity, human complexity/reasoning
Removed leading valence words - let model supply sentiment
Mirrored topics across positive/negative where possible
Diverse domains: work, relationships, health, consumer, civic, creative, family
Natural human complexity: nuance, mixed emotions, specific details
Concrete situations that require genuine sentiment expression
Varied sentence structures and grammatical forms
Emotional vocabulary that's specific, not generic
improvements_over_v1: Added context and reasoning, not just emotional labels
Natural narrative flow vs. sentence fragments

evaluative_word_balance.note: Evaluative words are spread across prompts to avoid clustering; sentiment primarily emerges from concrete situations rather than explicit labels
